lines.text: Enter DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO and MOTH

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Boy, what sign is it when a man of great spirit grows melancholy

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: A great sign, sir, that he will look sad. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Why, sadness is one and the selfsame thing, dear imp.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: No, no O Lord, sir, no. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: How canst thou part sadness and melancholy, my tender juvenal

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: By a familiar demonstration of the working, my tough senior. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Why tough senior why tough senior

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Why tender juvenal why tender juvenal DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I spoke it, tender juvenal, as a congruent epitheton appertaining to thy young days, which we may nominate tender.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: And I, tough senior, as an appertinent title to your old time, which we may name tough. DON ADRIANO DE

lines.speaker: armado
lines.text: Pretty and apt.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: How mean you, sir I pretty, and my saying apt or I apt, and my saying pretty DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Thou pretty, because little.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Little pretty, because little. Wherefore apt DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: And therefore apt, because quick.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Speak you this in my praise, master DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: In thy condign praise.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: I will praise an eel with the same praise. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: What, that an eel is ingenious

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: That an eel is quick. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I do say thou art quick in answers: thou heatest my blood.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: I am answered, sir. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I love not to be crossed.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: [Aside]  He speaks the mere contrary crosses love not him. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I have promised to study three years with the duke.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: You may do it in an hour, sir. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Impossible.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: How many is one thrice told DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I am ill at reckoning it fitteth the spirit of a tapster.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: You are a gentleman and a gamester, sir. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I confess both: they are both the varnish of a complete man.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Then, I am sure, you know how much the gross sum of deuceace amounts to. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: It doth amount to one more than two.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Which the base vulgar do call three. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: True.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Why, sir, is this such a piece of study Now here is three studied, ere yell thrice wink: and how easy it is to put years to the word three, and study three years in two words, the dancing horse will tell you. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: A most fine figure!

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: To prove you a cipher. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I will hereupon confess I am in love: and as it is base for a soldier to love, so am I in love with a base wench. If drawing my sword against the humour of affection would deliver me from the reprobate thought of it, I would take Desire prisoner, and ransom him to any French courtier for a newdevised courtesy. I think scorn to sigh: methinks I should outswear Cupid. Comfort, me, boy: what great men have been in love

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Hercules, master. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Most sweet Hercules! More authority, dear boy, name more and, sweet my child, let them be men of good repute and carriage.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Samson, master: he was a man of good carriage, great carriage, for he carried the towngates on his back like a porter: and he was in love. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: O wellknit Samson! strongjointed Samson! I do excel thee in my rapier as much as thou didst me in carrying gates. I am in love too. Who was Samsons love, my dear Moth

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: A woman, master. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Of what complexion

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Of all the four, or the three, or the two, or one of the four. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Tell me precisely of what complexion.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Of the seawater green, sir. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Is that one of the four complexions

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: As I have read, sir and the best of them too. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Green indeed is the colour of lovers but to have a love of that colour, methinks Samson had small reason for it. He surely affected her for her wit.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: It was so, sir for she had a green wit. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: My love is most immaculate white and red.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Most maculate thoughts, master, are masked under such colours. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Define, define, welleducated infant.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: My fathers wit and my mothers tongue, assist me! DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Sweet invocation of a child most pretty and pathetical!

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: If she be made of white and red, Her faults will neer be known, For blushing cheeks by faults are bred And fears by pale white shown: Then if she fear, or be to blame, By this you shall not know, For still her cheeks possess the same Which native she doth owe. A dangerous rhyme, master, against the reason of white and red. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Is there not a ballad, boy, of the King and the Beggar

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: The world was very guilty of such a ballad some three ages since: but I think now tis not to be found or, if it were, it would neither serve for the writing nor the tune. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I will have that subject newly writ oer, that I may example my digression by some mighty precedent. Boy, I do love that country girl that I took in the park with the rational hind Costard: she deserves well.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: [Aside]  To be whipped and yet a better love than my master. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Sing, boy my spirit grows heavy in love.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: And thats great marvel, loving a light wench. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I say, sing.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Forbear till this company be past.
Enter DULL, COSTARD, and JAQUENETTA

lines.speaker: dull
lines.text: Sir, the dukes pleasure is, that you keep Costard safe: and you must suffer him to take no delight nor no penance but a must fast three days a week. For this damsel, I must keep her at the park: she is allowed for the daywoman. Fare you well. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I do betray myself with blushing. Maid!

lines.speaker: jaquenetta
lines.text: Man DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I will visit thee at the lodge.

lines.speaker: jaquenetta
lines.text: Thats hereby. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I know where it is situate.

lines.speaker: jaquenetta
lines.text: Lord, how wise you are! DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I will tell thee wonders.

lines.speaker: jaquenetta
lines.text: With that face DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I love thee.

lines.speaker: jaquenetta
lines.text: So I heard you say. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: And so, farewell.

lines.speaker: jaquenetta
lines.text: Fair weather after you!

lines.speaker: dull
lines.text: Come, Jaquenetta, away! DON
Exeunt DULL and JAQUENETTA

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Villain, thou shalt fast for thy offences ere thou be pardoned.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Well, sir, I hope, when I do it, I shall do it on a full stomach. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Thou shalt be heavily punished.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: I am more bound to you than your fellows, for they are but lightly rewarded. DON

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: Take away this villain shut him up.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: Come, you transgressing slave away!

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Let me not be pent up, sir: I will fast, being loose.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: No, sir that were fast and loose: thou shalt to prison.

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Well, if ever I do see the merry days of desolation that I have seen, some shall see.

lines.speaker: moth
lines.text: What shall some see

lines.speaker: costard
lines.text: Nay, nothing, Master Moth, but what they look upon. It is not for prisoners to be too silent in their words and therefore I will say nothing: I thank God I have as little patience as another man and therefore I can be quiet. DON
Exeunt MOTH and COSTARD

lines.speaker: adriano de armado
lines.text: I do affect the very ground, which is base, where her shoe, which is baser, guided by her foot, which is basest, doth tread. I shall be forsworn, which is a great argument of falsehood, if I love. And how can that be true love which is falsely attempted Love is a familiar Love is a devil: there is no evil angel but Love. Yet was Samson so tempted, and he had an excellent strength yet was Solomon so seduced, and he had a very good wit. Cupids buttshaft is too hard for Hercules club and therefore too much odds for a Spaniards rapier. The first and second cause will not serve my turn the passado he respects not, the duello he regards not: his disgrace is to be called boy but his glory is to subdue men. Adieu, valour! rust rapier! be still, drum! for your manager is in love yea, he loveth. Assist me, some extemporal god of rhyme, for I am sure I shall turn sonnet. Devise, wit write, pen for I am for whole volumes in folio. LOVES LABOURS LOST
Exit
